name: Uniform boundedness conjecture for rational points
rephrased: For curves of fixed genus at least 2 defined over a fixed number field, the number of rational points is uniformly bounded.
implication_form: If a curve has genus at least 2 and is defined over a fixed number field, then the number of its rational points is bounded by a constant depending only on the number field and the genus.
explained: The Uniform Boundedness Conjecture for Rational Points states that for a fixed number field K and a fixed genus g â‰¥ 2, there exists a positive integer N(K, g) (depending only on K and g) such that every smooth, projective, geometrically connected curve of genus g defined over K that has at least one K-rational point has at most N(K, g) K-rational points. In other words, the number of rational points on such curves with a rational point is uniformly bounded across all curves of that genus over the fixed number field.
